content.description:
The chains are hard to reach. The rock is moss covered. The route is always shaded.

Usually these are major bummers, but look on the bright side: There is an anchor at the top to safely reach the chains, the moss is a beautiful green color and the shade from the tree keeps the route cool in the hot summer sun. Plus, this area of Cliff Drive is always open and never crowded, ever. Climb it!

•Out of respect to the original route creators – if anyone knows the original name of this route please leave it in a comment and it will be changed. Thank you.
content.protection: TR Chains. There is also a single anchor at the top set back from the edge to safely reach the chains for TR.
content.location: This is the 6th climb west of the access ramp on the main wall. Look for the big tree right out from the wall.

content.description: This is a project that will be a pretty good 5.10ish route with some cleaning. As it sits it is worth doing on TR, but it's a bit dirty and has some loose rock. It feels like a 10c or so, but could be easier or harder once it cleans up.
content.location: 4th route to the west of the access ramp on the main wall.

content.description: short route with a roof. It's a bit pumpy.
content.location: far left bolted route on the main wall

content.description:
Surprisingly challenging little route. So Far Gone is very "handsy." All the footholds are slippery and not obvious forcing the climber to rely on a strong upper body. The top features a slight overhang that isn't too challenging to get over but offers slight rain protection on drizzly days. Named "So Far Gone" due to it's far distance from the other routes in this beautifully overgrown and natural park.

Out of respect to the original route creators – if anyone knows the original name of this route please leave it in a comment and it will be changed. Thank you.
content.protection: 3 bolts with hangers to TR chains.
content.location: Last route to the west of the access ramp on the main wall. Almost to the end of the Edwidge Woldson Park. There is an alternate access point for this climb instead of taking the main access area: Walk down the Tiger Trail at the far west side of the park and turn right at the base of the crag, then walk 50 feet to the route.

content.description: Skipping Stones lives up to its name by being a fun, easy, short route but also probably the "wettest" route at the crag. The main wall curves in at Skipping Stones making it less steep and a perfect place for water to run down or skip over the rocks. Although always damp and not very desirable after a rain, Skipping Stones is just as dry as the rest of the wall on a sunny day and will be ready to climb! It is juggy and perfect to learn on to lead or top rope.
content.location: This is the third route east of the access ramp on the main wall. It is the route directly behind of the stump. Look for the water stain on the rock.

content.description: A fun, juggy route with just enough of an overhang to be a bit of a workout- if it weren't so short.
content.location: The second route east of the acces ramp.

content.description:
Secrets of Giants is a little harder and a little more rad than Skipping Stones to the right. It has a very short but fun overhanging section with huge holds at he beginning. Use upper body strength to get up and back to normal climbing to the top. The last fourth or so gets a little slick as it is exposed to rain water up high. This is a great route with a diverse and interesting start. It is also one of the tallest routes at the crag because it is one of the middle routes on the main wall.

Out of respect to the original route creators – if anyone knows the original name of this route please leave it in a comment and it will be changed. Thank you.
content.location: This is the fourth route east of the access ramp on the main wall. It is the second route to the left of the stump. Look for the chalk marks on the huge holds at the bottom to start the climb.

content.description:
There is a large rock a few paces to the north of the main wall. On the backside there are 3 beginner-friendly bolted routes. The three routes on this rock get their names from classic nursery rhymes. Peter Pan is the right route. This route is a few feet taller than the other two routes on this rock which is nice because these routes are pretty short. Even though they are short, they are still very fun though. Peter Pan has a couple small cracks that you can follow up the wall for a bit at the bottom. Also, there is a slightly confusing part about 3/4th of the way to the top which makes it a little more interesting.

Out of respect to the original route creators – if anyone knows the original name of this route please leave it in a comment and it will be changed. Thank you.
content.protection: 3 bolts with hangers to TR chains.
content.location: Right route on the backside of the large rock a few paces north from the main wall.

content.description: Go up the face of the pillar, most holds are good on the side. When you get to the top go to the right of the face and around the tree branch. If you go right up the final face it may be more like a. 5.8 move
content.location: On the back side of So Far Gone, the rock is mossed a little.

content.description:
There is a large rock a few paces to the north of the main wall. On the backside there are 3 beginner-friendly bolted routes. The three routes on this rock get their names from classic nursery rhymes. The Little Engine that Could  is the left route. This is the shortest of the three climbs. But even though it is the shortest, it feels like the hardest of the three which is great! But be careful of the tree next to the wall when repelling back down.

Out of respect to the original route creators – if anyone knows the original name of this route please leave it in a comment and it will be changed. Thank you.
content.protection: 2 bolts with hangers to TR chains. There is also an anchor at the top to safely reach the TR chains.
content.location: Left route on the backside of the large rock a few paces north from the main wall.

content.description: Life finds a way even on a volcanic basalt wall. Nature magically flourishes. Climb up and slightly to the left following the clean rock as you run parallel the waterfall of moss running down the right side of the route. As are you near the top head right for a few feet to hit the chains. This route is slightly tougher than the route to its left and slightly taller but still has nice big holds making it not too challenging. Heads-up: There are some loose rocks in the right mossy area.
content.protection: 3 bolts with hangers to chains. There is also a single anchor at the top set back from the edge to safely reach the chains for TR.
content.location: This is the third climb west of the access ramp on the main wall. Look for the route just left of the mossy water-stained basalt.

content.description: it's fun, it's juggy, and it's about 5.8.
content.location: The first route east of the acces ramp.

content.description:
Humpty Dumpty sat on the wall.. or there is a large rock a few paces to the north of the main wall. On the backside there are 3 beginner-friendly bolted routes. The three routes on this rock get their names from classic nursery rhymes. Humpty Dumpty is the middle route. This is a quick route with a beautiful view of downtown Spokane in the background. It would also be a great route to learn to lead on. It is the easiest of the three routes. Bring the kids!

Out of respect to the original route creators – if anyone knows the original name of this route please leave it in a comment and it will be changed. Thank you.
content.protection: 3 bolts with hangers to TR chains. There is a tree at the top to tie onto to safely reach the TR chains.
content.location: Middle route on the backside of the large rock a few paces north from the main wall.

content.description: This is a straight forward warmup route that ain't so bad. We just wish it was taller! It is protected from light rain by a large tree so it is climbable in slightly damp weather which is great. Just like The Cave Of Ashes, just to the left, it is a nice warmup route to complete before tackling some of the harder routes on the main wall. It has tons of large holds and more than enough bolts for protection.
content.protection: 3 bolts with hangers to chains. There is also a single anchor at the top set back from the edge to safely reach the chains for TR.
content.location: This is the second climb west of the access ramp on the main wall. Located on the outside wall of the small basalt cave.

content.description: A stiff 15-foot boulder problem right off the deck, followed by moderate but good climbing to the top. I think it's the best climb at the crag. Finding good feet at the second bolt is key.
content.location: It's the steep route in the center of the main wall.

content.description: Four bolts to chains. It’s smart to stick clip this one.
content.location:
Look for the TR anchors on the steepest part of the main wall, center.

Between Bum Camp and Fat Lip.

content.description: This is a fun climb up an open corner that is trickier than it looks. The right footwork makes it easy 5.9, grovel a bit and it'll feel harder.
content.location: 6th route from the left of the main wall

content.description: The Cave Of Ashes is a short fun warmup route that runs up the outside wall of a very small volcanic basalt cave. Start below the bolts and work your way up and slightly to the left almost wrapping yourself around the corner of the wall. It has tons of large holds and more than enough bolts for protection. This is a nice warmup route before tackling some of the harder routes on the main wall.
content.protection: 3 bolts with hangers to chains. There is also a single anchor set back from the edge to safely reach the chains for TR.
content.location: first climb west of the access ramp on the main wall

content.description:
The Cliff Drive climbs are all fun, short gym type climbs that can be pretty pumpy for the grade. If you you need a quick workout and don't want to pay for the gym, try this.

Some sidepulls will lead you to the crux left hand crimp above the second bolt. I think the bums may have stolen the clipping jug at the third bolt. It gets easier as you hit the blocky bucket at the fourth bolt.
content.location: 2nd from the left, main wall

content.description: This route is begins with a super fun overhanging section with huge holds. Upper body strength is required to climb over the lava flow hump and back to normal climbing to the top. The last fourth or so gets a little slick to your left side as it is exposed to rain water up high. This is a great route with a diverse and interesting start. It is also one of the tallest routes at the crag because it is one of the middle routes on the main wall.
content.location: This is the 6th route east of the access ramp on the main wall. It is the second route to the left of the stump. Look for the chalk marks on the huge holds at the bottom to start the climb.

content.description:
Named after volcanic basalt and the fact that rocks can come flying off the wall as you climb this route. It is exciting! Don't get one in the face though.

So currently there are lots of loose rocks. So be careful when climbing. But it's a fun challenging little route that should get harder once it is cleaned up.

Out of respect to the original route creators – if anyone knows the original name of this route please leave it in a comment and it will be changed. Thank you.
content.protection: TR Chains. There is also a single anchor at the top set back from the edge to safely reach the chains for TR.
content.location: This is the fourth climb west of the access ramp on the main wall.
